captions.text:
Good morning from the studio.
It is Thursday, October 24,
2024. I am Gary Thompson.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
I am coming to you
after a fairly standard commute
from South Brooklyn. The cats
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
were acting up this morning,
and the guinea pigs were
whistling for their carrots before
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
the sun was even up,
but we made it. My
kids are off to school,
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
and I am here in
Jersey City ready to look
at the news through a
captions.speaker: A
A

captions.text:
figure who has been in
the public eye for two
decades but seems to be
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
hitting a new gear of
professional maturity. We are talking
about Selena Gomez. Margaret, you
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
have been tracking the dispatches
coming out of Georgia over
the last twenty-four hours. What
captions.speaker: A

captions.text: is the latest?
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
Thanks, Gary. It has been
a very busy window for
Selena Gomez. Just yesterday, October
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
23, she was down in
Georgia for the SCAD Savannah
Film Festival. This is a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
big stop on the awards
circuit, and she was there
to receive the Virtuoso Award.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
This is specifically for her
performance in the new film
Emilia Pérez. It is a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Jacques Audiard film, a Spanish-language
musical about a cartel leader
who seeks gender-affirming surgery. Selena
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
plays Jessi, the wife of
the cartel leader. The buzz
coming out of Savannah is
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
intense. People are calling this
the definitive pivot in her
career. She was seen on
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
the red carpet in a
very understated, elegant black gown,
greeting fans, but the real
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
meat of the story is
the interview she gave regarding
her craft and her future.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
You know, Margaret, I look
at someone like Selena Gomez
and I think about the
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
institutions of celebrity. We have
seen so many people who
start as child stars and
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
then the wheels come off
because there is no accountability
or no long-term plan. But
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
what I am seeing here,
especially with this Virtuoso Award
on October 23, is a
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
person who is treating her
career like a serious trade.
She is forty-three years old—wait,
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
no, I am forty-three, she
is thirty-two—but she has the
poise of someone who has
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
been working a steady job
for thirty years. She is
showing up, doing the work,
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
and now she is being
recognized by the film community,
not just the pop music
captions.speaker: A

captions.text: world.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
It is interesting you mention
the work, Gary, because I
want to push back a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
little on the idea that
this is just a "steady
job." This film, Emilia Pérez,
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
is a massive risk. It
is a musical about the
Mexican cartel. She is singing
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
in Spanish. In her interviews
yesterday with The Hollywood Reporter
and Variety, she admitted that
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
she was terrified of the
role. She said she felt
she had to prove she
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
belonged in that space. Now,
as a skeptic, I have
to ask: is this Virtuoso
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Award just part of a
very well-oiled Oscar campaign machine?
Netflix is pushing this film
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
hard. They have a release
date of November 13 coming
up. Is she actually a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
virtuoso, or is she just
the most famous person in
a very artistic film?
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
That is a fair question,
Margaret. We have to distinguish
between the marketing and the
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
merit. But look at the
facts of the performance. She
is working with Jacques Audiard,
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
a director who does not
suffer fools. He is a
Palme d'Or winner. If she
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
did not have the chops,
she would not be in
the frame. What I appreciate,
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
from a pragmatic standpoint, is
that she is not resting
on her laurels. She has
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
the most followed Instagram account
for a woman, she has
a billion-dollar beauty brand in
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
Rare Beauty, and she could
easily just sit back and
collect checks. Instead, she is
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
in Savannah, Georgia, on a
Wednesday night, talking about the
technical challenges of singing in
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
her native language, which she
has admitted she had to
work hard to reclaim. That
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
shows a level of professional
accountability that I respect.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
She did speak about that
specifically yesterday. She mentioned to
Entertainment Weekly that singing in
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Spanish for this role was
a different kind of vulnerability.
It wasn't just about hitting
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
the notes; it was about
the character's pain. And she
linked that to her own
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
life. She has been very
open lately about her health
struggles and the fact that
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
she cannot carry her own
children. Some might say she
is oversharing, Gary. Is there
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
a point where the personal
brand and the professional work
become too blurred? Does knowing
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
about her medical history make
her a better actress, or
is it just part of
captions.speaker: B

captions.text: the modern celebrity industrial complex?
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
I will say, though, that
her fans in Savannah yesterday
did not seem to care
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
about the "industrial complex" part.
There are reports from the
Daily Mail and local outlets
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
that she spent a significant
amount of time with the
students at the Savannah College
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
of Art and Design. She
wasn't just there for the
trophy; she was doing a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
masterclass. She told them that
vulnerability is a strength, not
a weakness. I find that
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
plausible, but also a bit
of a convenient narrative for
someone who is currently the
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
face of a "mental health
focused" beauty brand.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
See, Margaret, this is where
we might disagree on the
"convenience" of it. I look
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
at it as a father.
I have three kids. I
want them to see people
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
in positions of power who
are honest about their limitations.
If she is using her
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
platform to say, "Hey, I
have these health issues, I
have these struggles, but I
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
am still showing up to
work and winning awards," that
provides a stable roadmap for
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
young people. It is not
extremist; it is just human.
And the fact that she
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
is doing this while her
show, Only Murders in the
Building, is wrapping up another
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
successful season shows she is
managing multiple high-level responsibilities. That
is a lot of balls
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
to keep in the air
without dropping them.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
Let's talk about the Oscar
buzz specifically, because that was
a major theme in the
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Rolling Stone and Variety pieces
from the last twenty-four hours.
The critics are placing her
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
firmly in the Supporting Actress
race. If she gets the
nomination, she becomes one of
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
the few Disney alumni to
really cross over into that
top-tier Academy circle. But Gary,
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
the film is a musical.
Some critics at the BBC
have noted that the genre-bending
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
nature of Emilia Pérez might
be too "out there" for
the traditional Academy voters. Do
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
you think her public image,
which is very grounded and
"plainspoken" as you like to
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
say, helps bridge that gap
for a movie that is
essentially a French-directed Mexican cartel
captions.speaker: B

captions.text: musical?
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
I think it does. People
trust her. They feel they
know her. In a world
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
where everything feels like an
act, her brand of "lived
experience" feels authentic to people.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
Whether it is 100% authentic
or 80% authentic doesn't matter
as much as the fact
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
that it functions as a
stabilizing force in her career.
She isn't chasing trends. She
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
isn't trying to be a
"diva." She is in Savannah
talking to film students. That
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
is a very "working class"
approach to being a global
superstar. She is putting in
captions.speaker: A

captions.text: the hours.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
I will concede that the
Rare Impact Fund, which she
also discussed yesterday, is a
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
concrete institution. It is not
just a hashtag. They are
actually putting money into mental
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
health services in schools. That
aligns with your value of
institutions, Gary. She is building
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
something that outlasts a movie's
theatrical run. However, I do
wonder if the pressure of
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
being this "perfectly vulnerable" role
model is sustainable. She mentioned
in The Hollywood Reporter yesterday
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
that she sometimes feels the
weight of everyone's expectations. She
said, and I am paraphrasing,
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
that she has to be
careful not to lose herself
in the "Selena Gomez" of
captions.speaker: B

captions.text: it all.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
That is the risk of
the job. But look at
the alternative. We see so
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
many people in her position
who flame out because they
have no foundation. She has
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
her family, she has her
business, and she has a
clear sense of her own
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
limitations. To me, that is
the definition of a virtuoso—not
just someone who is good
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
at their craft, but someone
who understands the instrument they
are playing, which in this
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
case is her own life
and career.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
It is a compelling argument.
And the timing is perfect.
With the Savannah Film Festival
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
giving her this platform right
now, she is effectively kicking
off the final sprint for
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
the year. We have the
Netflix release in three weeks.
We have the soundtrack for
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Emilia Pérez which is already
getting traction on Billboard. She
is effectively dominating the film,
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
music, and business news cycles
simultaneously this morning.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
And she is doing it
without a scandal. In this
day and age, that is
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
a feat in itself. No
extremism, no public meltdowns, just
a professional at the top
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
of her game receiving an
award in Georgia. It is
a reminder that long-term stability
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
comes from consistent work and
a bit of humility. Margaret,
I think we have defined
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
the standard here. She is
setting a bar for how
to transition from a teen
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
idol to a serious institutional
player in Hollywood.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
I agree with that. Even
a skeptic like me has
to admit that the sheer
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
volume of her output, and
the quality of the collaborators
she is choosing, suggests this
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
isn't a fluke. It is
a calculated, well-executed career phase.
Whether the Oscar comes or
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
not, the Virtuoso Award she
picked up yesterday marks a
turning point.
captions.speaker: B

captions.text:
Well said. To summarize for
our listeners: Selena Gomez was
in Savannah, Georgia, on October
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
23, 2024, to receive the
Virtuoso Award for her role
in Emilia Pérez. She is
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
navigating a heavy awards season
while maintaining her business interests
and being open about her
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
personal health challenges. It is
a masterclass in professional management.
We will be watching how
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
the public responds when the
film hits Netflix on November
13. That is our deep
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
dive for this morning. I
am Gary Thompson.
captions.speaker: A

captions.text:
And I am Margaret Butcher.
We will see you tomorrow.
captions.speaker: B

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: Good morning from the studio. It is Thursday, October 24, 2024. I am Gary Thompson. I am coming to you after a fairly standard commute from South Brooklyn. The cats were acting up this morning, and the guinea pigs were whistling for their carrots before the sun was even up, but we made it. My kids are off to school, and I am here in Jersey City ready to look at the news through a lens of what actually matters for the long term. Today, we are talking about a figure who has been in the public eye for two decades but seems to be hitting a new gear of professional maturity. We are talking about Selena Gomez. Margaret, you have been tracking the dispatches coming out of Georgia over the last twenty-four hours. What is the latest?

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: Thanks, Gary. It has been a very busy window for Selena Gomez. Just yesterday, October 23, she was down in Georgia for the SCAD Savannah Film Festival. This is a big stop on the awards circuit, and she was there to receive the Virtuoso Award. This is specifically for her performance in the new film Emilia Pérez. It is a Jacques Audiard film, a Spanish-language musical about a cartel leader who seeks gender-affirming surgery. Selena plays Jessi, the wife of the cartel leader. The buzz coming out of Savannah is intense. People are calling this the definitive pivot in her career. She was seen on the red carpet in a very understated, elegant black gown, greeting fans, but the real meat of the story is the interview she gave regarding her craft and her future.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: You know, Margaret, I look at someone like Selena Gomez and I think about the institutions of celebrity. We have seen so many people who start as child stars and then the wheels come off because there is no accountability or no long-term plan. But what I am seeing here, especially with this Virtuoso Award on October 23, is a person who is treating her career like a serious trade. She is forty-three years old—wait, no, I am forty-three, she is thirty-two—but she has the poise of someone who has been working a steady job for thirty years. She is showing up, doing the work, and now she is being recognized by the film community, not just the pop music world.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: It is interesting you mention the work, Gary, because I want to push back a little on the idea that this is just a "steady job." This film, Emilia Pérez, is a massive risk. It is a musical about the Mexican cartel. She is singing in Spanish. In her interviews yesterday with The Hollywood Reporter and Variety, she admitted that she was terrified of the role. She said she felt she had to prove she belonged in that space. Now, as a skeptic, I have to ask: is this Virtuoso Award just part of a very well-oiled Oscar campaign machine? Netflix is pushing this film hard. They have a release date of November 13 coming up. Is she actually a virtuoso, or is she just the most famous person in a very artistic film?

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: That is a fair question, Margaret. We have to distinguish between the marketing and the merit. But look at the facts of the performance. She is working with Jacques Audiard, a director who does not suffer fools. He is a Palme d'Or winner. If she did not have the chops, she would not be in the frame. What I appreciate, from a pragmatic standpoint, is that she is not resting on her laurels. She has the most followed Instagram account for a woman, she has a billion-dollar beauty brand in Rare Beauty, and she could easily just sit back and collect checks. Instead, she is in Savannah, Georgia, on a Wednesday night, talking about the technical challenges of singing in her native language, which she has admitted she had to work hard to reclaim. That shows a level of professional accountability that I respect.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: She did speak about that specifically yesterday. She mentioned to Entertainment Weekly that singing in Spanish for this role was a different kind of vulnerability. It wasn't just about hitting the notes; it was about the character's pain. And she linked that to her own life. She has been very open lately about her health struggles and the fact that she cannot carry her own children. Some might say she is oversharing, Gary. Is there a point where the personal brand and the professional work become too blurred? Does knowing about her medical history make her a better actress, or is it just part of the modern celebrity industrial complex?

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: I will say, though, that her fans in Savannah yesterday did not seem to care about the "industrial complex" part. There are reports from the Daily Mail and local outlets that she spent a significant amount of time with the students at the Savannah College of Art and Design. She wasn't just there for the trophy; she was doing a masterclass. She told them that vulnerability is a strength, not a weakness. I find that plausible, but also a bit of a convenient narrative for someone who is currently the face of a "mental health focused" beauty brand.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: See, Margaret, this is where we might disagree on the "convenience" of it. I look at it as a father. I have three kids. I want them to see people in positions of power who are honest about their limitations. If she is using her platform to say, "Hey, I have these health issues, I have these struggles, but I am still showing up to work and winning awards," that provides a stable roadmap for young people. It is not extremist; it is just human. And the fact that she is doing this while her show, Only Murders in the Building, is wrapping up another successful season shows she is managing multiple high-level responsibilities. That is a lot of balls to keep in the air without dropping them.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: Let's talk about the Oscar buzz specifically, because that was a major theme in the Rolling Stone and Variety pieces from the last twenty-four hours. The critics are placing her firmly in the Supporting Actress race. If she gets the nomination, she becomes one of the few Disney alumni to really cross over into that top-tier Academy circle. But Gary, the film is a musical. Some critics at the BBC have noted that the genre-bending nature of Emilia Pérez might be too "out there" for the traditional Academy voters. Do you think her public image, which is very grounded and "plainspoken" as you like to say, helps bridge that gap for a movie that is essentially a French-directed Mexican cartel musical?

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: I think it does. People trust her. They feel they know her. In a world where everything feels like an act, her brand of "lived experience" feels authentic to people. Whether it is 100% authentic or 80% authentic doesn't matter as much as the fact that it functions as a stabilizing force in her career. She isn't chasing trends. She isn't trying to be a "diva." She is in Savannah talking to film students. That is a very "working class" approach to being a global superstar. She is putting in the hours.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: I will concede that the Rare Impact Fund, which she also discussed yesterday, is a concrete institution. It is not just a hashtag. They are actually putting money into mental health services in schools. That aligns with your value of institutions, Gary. She is building something that outlasts a movie's theatrical run. However, I do wonder if the pressure of being this "perfectly vulnerable" role model is sustainable. She mentioned in The Hollywood Reporter yesterday that she sometimes feels the weight of everyone's expectations. She said, and I am paraphrasing, that she has to be careful not to lose herself in the "Selena Gomez" of it all.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: That is the risk of the job. But look at the alternative. We see so many people in her position who flame out because they have no foundation. She has her family, she has her business, and she has a clear sense of her own limitations. To me, that is the definition of a virtuoso—not just someone who is good at their craft, but someone who understands the instrument they are playing, which in this case is her own life and career.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: It is a compelling argument. And the timing is perfect. With the Savannah Film Festival giving her this platform right now, she is effectively kicking off the final sprint for the year. We have the Netflix release in three weeks. We have the soundtrack for Emilia Pérez which is already getting traction on Billboard. She is effectively dominating the film, music, and business news cycles simultaneously this morning.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: And she is doing it without a scandal. In this day and age, that is a feat in itself. No extremism, no public meltdowns, just a professional at the top of her game receiving an award in Georgia. It is a reminder that long-term stability comes from consistent work and a bit of humility. Margaret, I think we have defined the standard here. She is setting a bar for how to transition from a teen idol to a serious institutional player in Hollywood.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: I agree with that. Even a skeptic like me has to admit that the sheer volume of her output, and the quality of the collaborators she is choosing, suggests this isn't a fluke. It is a calculated, well-executed career phase. Whether the Oscar comes or not, the Virtuoso Award she picked up yesterday marks a turning point.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: A
dialogue_chunks.text: Well said. To summarize for our listeners: Selena Gomez was in Savannah, Georgia, on October 23, 2024, to receive the Virtuoso Award for her role in Emilia Pérez. She is navigating a heavy awards season while maintaining her business interests and being open about her personal health challenges. It is a masterclass in professional management. We will be watching how the public responds when the film hits Netflix on November 13. That is our deep dive for this morning. I am Gary Thompson.

dialogue_chunks.speaker: B
dialogue_chunks.text: And I am Margaret Butcher. We will see you tomorrow.
